query: What is the theoretical lower bound for Christmas tree polygon packing in a square bounding box?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: The theoretical lower bound for Christmas tree polygon packing in a square bounding box is not explicitly specified in the search results; however, related packing problems suggest that bounds are often derived from area considerations and geometric constraints, with some results indicating that the minimal side length must be at least proportional to the square root of the number of polygons, such as for squares where s(n) ≥ √n ([Friedman, 2009](https://erich-friedman.github.io/papers/squares/squares.html)).

[THEELECTRONICJOURNAL OFCOMBINATORICS](http://www.combinatorics.org/)(2009), DS#7.
Packing Unit Squares inSquares:
A Survey and New Results
[Erich Friedman](https://erich-friedman.github.io/)
[Stetson University, DeLand, FL32723](http://www.stetson.edu)
Abstract
Let s(n) be the side of the smallest square into which we can pack n unit squares. We present a history of this problem, and give the best known upper and lower bounds for s(n) for n≤100, including the best known packings. We also give relatively simple proofs for the values of s(n) when n = 2,3, 5, 8, 15, 24, and 35, and more complicated proofs for n=7 and 14. We also prove manyother lower bounds for various s(n).
Table of Contents
[1. Introduction](#introduction)
[2. Previous Results](#previousresults)
[3. New Packings](#newpackings)
[4. Technical Lemmas](#technicallemmas)
[5. Lower Bounds](#lowerbounds)
[Appendix](#appendix)
[References](#references)
1 Introduction
The problem of packing equal circles in a square has been around for some 40 years and has seenmuch recent progress[[2]](#references). The problemof packing equal squares in a square is only recently becoming well known. Results were less plentiful, asthe computer-aided methods available for circles did not generalize for squares, until recently when an
effective algorithm was found[[20]](#references). We give a few packings which improve upon those in the literature, illustrate a technique forobtaining lower bounds, and exhibit the best known packings for less than one hundred squares.
Let s(n) be the side of the smallest square into which we can pack n unit squares. It isclear that √n ≤ s(n) ≤![](pic/lceil.gif)√n![](pic/rceil.gif), the firstinequality coming from area considerations, and the second coming from the facts that s(n) isnon-decreasing and s(n2)=n. It is not hard to show that s(2)=s(3)=2. It is a littleharder to show that s(5)=2+1/√2[[7]](#references).
The number of claims far outweighs the number of published results in this area. Göbel saysthat Schrijver claims that Bajmóoczy proved s(7)=s(8)=3[[7]](#references). Walter Stromquist claimed to have proved s(6)=3 ands(10)=3+1/√2, and claimed to know how to prove s(14)=s(15)=4 and s(24)=5[[13]](#references). Trevor Green sent me a proof for s(6)=3. None of these proofs were published. Said El Moumni evidently proved s(7)=s(8)=3 and s(15)=4[[12]](#references)but no one was aware of this until recently. Finally, in 2002, Kearney and Shiu published a proof of s(6)=3[[9]](#references).
In 2003, Stromquist proved s(10)=3+1/√2[[18]](#references).
In 2005, Nagamochi proved that s(n2-2)=s(n2-1)=n[[19]](#references). Also in 2005, Thierry Gensane and Philippe Ryckelynck published an inflation algorithm for finding good packings and found the first computer packing that might be optimal.[[20]](#references). There are many other good packings thought to be optimal, but as of yet no proofs.Here we prove the values of s(n) for square n and n=2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 14, 15, 24, and 35.
Previous results can be found in[Section 2](#previousresults). Reccent packings appear in[Section 3](#newpackings). In[Section 4](#technicallemmas)we prove some technical lemmas that we use in[Section 5](#lowerbounds)to prove the values of s(n) mentioned above. Lists of the bestknown upper and lower bounds for s(n) are given in the[Appendix](#appendix). Many of the results given aretaken from unpublished letters and manuscripts, and private communications.
2 Previous Results
Göbel was the first to publish on the subject[[7]](#references). He found that a2+a+3+![](pic/lfloor.gif)(a-1)√2![](pic/rfloor.gif)squares can be packed in a square of sidea+1+1/√2 by placing a diagonal strip of squares at a 45oangle. This gives the best known packings for all values of a except for a=3 and a=6 (see Figure 1).

By unrotating some rotated squares in the corner, we get some alternate packings for n=10, 67,and 84. (see Figure 2). David Cantell noticed in 2005 that alternative packings exist for n=27, 38, 52, and 84 using a minimum number of rotated squares (see Figure 2)[[17]](#references).

It is clear that n+2![](pic/lfloor.gif)s(n)![](pic/rfloor.gif)+1 squares can be packed in a square of side s(n)+1 by packing n squares insidea square of side s(n) and putting the other squares in an "L" around it. The first four packings inFigure 2 are of this form. Packings not containing an "L" of squares we will call*primitive*packings. From now on, we will only illustrate primitive packings.
Göbel also found that if integers a andb satisfied a-1<b/√2<a+1, then 2a2+2a+b2squarescan be packed inside a square of side a+1+b/√2. This is accomplished byplacing a b × b square of squares at a 45oangle in the center. This gives the bestknown packings for 28, 40, 65, and 89 squares (see Figure 3). Adding an "L" around the packing of 65
squares gives the best known packing of 82 squares. The packing for n=40 is rigid.
![](pic/s28.gif)

Charles Cottingham, who improved some of Göbel's packings for n≤49, wasthe first to use diagonal strips of width 2[[6]](#references). Soon after he produced a packing of 19 squares with a diagonal strip of width 2, RobertWainwright improved Cottingham's packing slightly (see Figure 4)[[4]](#references). In 2002, David Cantrell found some alternative packings for 19 squares[[14]](#references).
![](pic/s19.gif)

In 1980, Evert Stenlund improved many of Cottingham's packings, and provided packings for n≤100[[6]](#references). His packing of 66squares uses a diagonal strip of width 3 (see Figure 5). In this packing, the diagonal squarestouch only the squares in the upper right and lower left corners. Adding an "L" to this packinggives the best known packing of 83 squares.
![](pic/s66.gif)
s(66)≤3+4√2
Figure 5.|
The best known packings for many values of n are more complicated. Many seem to requirepacking with squares at angles other than 0oand 45o. In 1979, WalterTrump improved Göbel's packing of 11 squares (see Figure 6). Many people haveindependently discovered this packing. The original discovery has been incorrectly attributedto Gustafson and Thule[[11]](#references). The middlesquares are tilted about 40.182o, and there is a small gap between these squares. This packing is also rigid.
![](pic/s11.gif)
s(11)<3.8771
Figure 6.|
In 1980, Hämäläinen improved on Göbel's packing of 18 squares(see Figure 7)[[6]](#references). In 1981, MatsGustafson found an alternative optimal packing of 18 squares (see Figure 7). The middle squaresin these packings are tilted by an angle of arcsin((√7-1)/4)≈24.295o. In 2002, David Cantrell
found another alternative packing (see Figure 7)[[14]](#references)that is useful in building the best known packing for n=68 (see[Figure 11](#figure11)). In 2004, the computer program of Gensane and Ryckelynck found yet another alternative packing (see Figure 7)[[20]](#references).

Packing rectangles into a large square
Janusz Januszewski
Published online: 6 February 2015
© The Author(s) 2015. This article is published with open access at Springerlink.com
Abstract If c > 5 and if x is sufficiently large, then any collection of rectangles of sides of
length not greater than 1 with total area smaller than x2 −cx5/6 can be packed into a square
of side length x.
Keywords Packing · Rectangle · Square
Mathematics Subject Classification 52C15
1 Introduction
First publications related to packing of rectangles or squares appeared over fifty years ago.
In 1957 Kosi ´nski [6] proved, among others, that any sequence of rectangles of total area V
and with sides of length not greater than D can be packed into a rectangle of side lengths 3D
and (V + D2)/D. This result was improved in [4,7,8]. Other problems related to this subject
were outlined in the sixties of the last century by L. Moser [9]. He asked, for example, “Can
every set of rectangles of total area 1 and maximal side 1 be accommodated in a square of
area 2?” (the answer is positive [5]) or “What is the smallest number A such that any set of
squares of total area 1 can be packed into some rectangle of area A?” (some bounds are given
in [3,10,11]). The question of packing of equal squares into a square as small as possible
was posed in [2].
Let Ix be a square of side length x. We say that a collection R1, R2,... of rectangles can
be packed into Ix , if it is possible to apply translations and rotations to the sets Ri so that
the resulting translated and rotated rectangles are contained in Ix and have mutually disjoint
interiors. Denote by s(x) the greatest number such that any collection of rectangles of sides
of length not greater than 1 with total area smaller than s(x) can be packed into Ix .
J. Januszewski (B)

results.title: Improved Approximations for Translational Packing of Convex Polygons
results.text:
Improved Approximations for Translational Packing
of Convex Polygons
Adam Kurpisz # Ñ 
Bern University of Applied Sciences and Department of Mathematics, ETH Zurich, Switzerland
Silvan Suter # 
Department of Mathematics, ETH Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract
Optimal packing of objects in containers is a critical problem in various real-life and industrial
applications. This paper investigates the two-dimensional packing of convex polygons without
rotations, where only translations are allowed. We study different settings depending on the type of
containers used, including minimizing the number of containers or the size of the container based on
an objective function.
Building on prior research in the field, we develop polynomial-time algorithms with improved
approximation guarantees upon the best-known results by Alt, de Berg and Knauer, as well as
Aamand, Abrahamsen, Beretta and Kleist, for problems such as Polygon Area Minimization, Polygon
Perimeter Minimization, Polygon Strip Packing, and Polygon Bin Packing. Our approach utilizes a
sequence of object transformations that allows sorting by height and orientation, thus enhancing
the effectiveness of shelf packing algorithms for polygon packing problems. In addition, we present
efficient approximation algorithms for special cases of the Polygon Bin Packing problem, progressing
toward solving an open question concerning an O(1)-approximation algorithm for arbitrary polygons.
2012 ACM Subject Classification Theory of computation → Packing and covering problems
Keywords and phrases Approximation algorithms, Packing problems, Convex polygons, Bin packing,
Strip packing, Area minimization
Related Version This is the full version of the same-named ESA 2023 paper. A link will be provided
in a future version of this document.
arXiv:2308.08523v1 [cs.CG] 16 Aug 2023
2 Improved Approximations for Translational Packing of Convex Polygons
1 Introduction
Many real-life situations require us to make decisions about optimally packing a collection
of objects into a specific container. One particular category of these packing problems is
two-dimensional packing, which is encountered in everyday scenarios like arranging items
on a shelf and in industrial applications such as cutting cookies from rolled-out dough
or manufacturing sets of tiles from standard-sized panels made of wood, glass, or metal.
Another intriguing example involves cutting fabric pieces for clothing production. In this
case, the pieces often cannot be rotated freely, as they must adhere to a desired pattern
in the final product, which is tailored of multiple elements. The widespread applicability
of two-dimensional packing problems has led to a surge of interest in designing efficient
algorithms to address them. In this paper, we follow the line of research and study the
problem of packing convex polygons without rotations in various settings depending on the
type of containers used.
Past research focusing on theoretical considerations of two-dimensional packings mainly
concentrates on the scenario when all objects are axis-parallel rectangles. In this paper, we
will discuss packing without rotations, in which only translations are permitted. There are
two main classes of the problem depending on whether the size of the container is fixed and
we want to minimize the number of containers used or whether we want to minimize the
container’s size with respect to some objective function.
A seminal example of the first class is the Geometric Bin Packing problem in which
a number of unit size squared bins to pack is to be minimized. The problem is arguably
the most natural generalization of the regular (1D) Bin Packing to two dimensions, and
its absolute approximability has been fully understood. Unless P = N P, the best possible
efficient constant factor approximation is 2 [15], and such an algorithm is known [10].
In the second class, there are several variants to be considered. An example is the
Strip Packing Problem which is concerned with packing objects into a strip of width
1 and infinite height in such a way that the maximum of all the heights of the placed
objects is minimized. Like Geometric Bin Packing, Strip Packing generalizes (1D)
Bin Packing. The best known efficient constant factor approximation for Strip Packing
has approximation factor (5/3 + ϵ) [9]. It is known that there can not exist a polynomial
time algorithm with an approximation ratio of (3/2 − ϵ) for any ϵ > 0 unless P = N P, which
follows directly from the approximation hardness of (1D) Bin Packing. Both classes of
problems have been also considered in the asymptotic setting, see e.g. [11, 5, 12].
In younger time, there was also an increase of interest in cases where the objects in
question are general convex polygons. Alt, de Berg and Knauer [2, 3] considered the problem
of packing an instance consisting of a number of convex polygons of the form p ⊂ [0, 1]2into
a minimum area axis-parallel rectangular container. We refer to this problem as Polygon
Area Minimization throughout this paper. In the special case where the instance consists
of rectangles only, the problem is known to admit a PTAS [4]. They proved the existence of
the following efficient algorithm:
A 23.78-approximation for Polygon Area Minimization.
Recently, Aamand, Abrahamsen, Beretta and Kleist [1] showed that the algorithm of Alt,
de Berg and Knauer can be leveraged to obtain also efficient approximation algorithms of
further problems:
A 7-approximation for Polygon Perimeter Minimization.
A 51-approximation for Polygon Strip Packing.
An 11-approximation for Polygon Bin Packing for polygons with diameter at most 1
10 .
A. Kurpisz and S. Suter 3
1.1 Our results
The results of Alt, de Berg and Knauer [2, 3] and Aamand et al. [1] are heavily based on
so-called shelf packing algorithms. In shelf packing algorithms, the objects are first placed
on the shelves, possibly ordered by height, which are later stacked on one another to build
a final solution. Compared to axis-parallel rectangles, the main challenge in designing an
approximation algorithm for polygon packing problems is that objects cannot be sorted by
height and orientation simultaneously. As a result, the algorithm and its analysis in [2, 3]
have such a large approximation guarantee. In this paper, we provide new insight into how
shelf packing algorithms should be applied to polygon packing problems. We introduce a
sequence of transformations of the objects that allow us first to sort them by height and later
by orientation to build a solution of a much better approximation guarantee. More precisely,
we design polynomial-time algorithms with the following factors:
A 9.45-approximation for Polygon Area Minimization.
Using this algorithm as a subroutine, we build upon the methods from Aamand et al. [1] to
obtain the following efficient approximation algorithms:
A (3.75 + ϵ)-approximation for Polygon Perimeter Minimization.
A 21.89-approximation for Polygon Strip Packing.
A 5.09-approximation for Polygon Bin Packing for polygons which have their diameter
bounded by 1
10 .
The results are proved in Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 respectively. Furthermore, in Section 8
we show the following results, which make progress towards solving an open question of a
O(1)-approximation algorithm for Polygon Bin Packing for arbitrary polygons.
There is an efficient O(
1
δ
)-approximation algorithm for Polygon Bin Packing for
instances where each polygon has width or height at most 1 − δ.
There is an efficient O(1)-approximation algorithm for Polygon Bin Packing for
instances with the property that all polygons share a spine (up to translation) with height
at least 3
4
.
2 Preliminaries
We start out considerations by recalling a classical and well-known problem in theoretical
computer science, the Bin Packing problem: Given a list of numbers s1, . . . , sn ∈ (0, 1] ∩ Q,
representing the sizes of n objects, the goal is to find the minimum number of bins of size 1,
so that we can pac...

results.title: Circle Packing for Origami Design Is Hard
results.text:
# Computer Science > Computational Geometry **arXiv:1008.1224** (cs) \[Submitted on 6 Aug 2010 ( [v1](https://arxiv.org/abs/1008.1224v1)), last revised 20 Sep 2010 (this version, v2)\] # Title:Circle Packing for Origami Design Is Hard Authors: [Erik D. Demaine](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Demaine,+E+D), [Sandor P. Fekete](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Fekete,+S+P), [Robert J. Lang](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Lang,+R+J) View a PDF of the paper titled Circle Packing for Origami Design Is Hard, by Erik D. Demaine and 2 other authors [View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1008.1224) > Abstract:We show that deciding whether a given set of circles can be packed into a rectangle, an equilateral triangle, or a unit square are NP-hard problems, settling the complexity of these natural packing problems. On the positive side, we show that any set of circles of total area 1 can be packed into a square of size 4/\\sqrt{pi}=2.2567... These results are motivated by problems arising in the context of origami design. | | | | --- | --- | | Comments: | 17 pages, 13 figures. ## Abstract

An algorithm is presented that can be used to pack sets of squares (or rectangles) into rectangles. The algorithm is applied to three open problems and will show how the best known results can be improved by a factor of at least 6×106in the first two problems and 2×106in the third.

In this paper, we prove that for any 1/2<t<1, there exists a positive integer N0 depending on _t_ such that for any n0≥N0, squares of sidelength f(n)−t for n≥n0 can be packed with disjoint interiors into a square of area ∑n=n0∞f(n)−2t, if the function _f_ satisfies some suitable conditions. [![Computational Geometry](https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925772111X00056-cov150h.gif)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/computational-geometry/vol/44/issue/8)

# On packing squares into a rectangle

Author links open overlay panelStefanHougardy

Show more

Outline

Add to Mendeley

Share

Cite

[https://doi.org/10.1016/j.comgeo.2011.05.001](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.comgeo.2011.05.001) [Get rights and content](https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&contentID=S0925772111000319&orderBeanReset=true)

Under an Elsevier [user license](http://www.elsevier.com/open-access/userlicense/1.0/)

open archive

## Abstract

We prove that every set of squares with total area 1 can be packed into a rectangle of area at most 2867/2048=1.399… . This improves on the previous best bound of 1.53. Also, our proof yields a linear time algorithm for finding such a packing.

- [Previous article in issue](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000307)
- Next article in issue

## 1\. Introduction

In 1966 Moser [\[15\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0150), [\[16\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0160) posed the following problem:

> What is the smallest number _A_ such that every set of squares of total area 1 can be accommodated in some rectangle of area _A_?

Here, “accommodated” means that the rectangle and squares must be axis-parallel and no two squares [intersect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/mathematics/intersects) in their interiors. See [Fig. 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#fg0010) for an example.

![](https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925772111000319-gr001.jpg)

1. [Download : Download full-size image](https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925772111000319-gr001.jpg)

Fig. 1. A packing of 12 squares into a rectangle.

Moon and Moser [\[14\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0140) proved that 1.2⩽A⩽2. Kleitman and Krieger [\[7\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0070) improved this, showing that A⩽3<1.733 and then later that A⩽4/6<1.633 [\[8\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0080). The previously best bounds are due to Novotný, who showed that A⩾(2+3)/3>1.244 [\[17\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0170) — which is easily seen by considering a square with area 1/2 and three squares each with area 1/6 — and later that A<1.53 [\[18\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0180). In this paper we improve on these results by showing that A⩽2867/2048=1.39990… .

**Theorem 1**

_Any set of squares with total area_ 1 _can be packed into a rectangle of area_ 2867/2048 _._

[Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#tl0010) summarizes the progress on upper bounds for Moserʼs problem. For more background, see the paper by Moser [\[16\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0160), and the book by Croft et al. [\[3\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0030) or Brass et al. [\[2\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0020).

Table 1. Progress on the upper bound for the smallest area of a rectangle into which one can pack every set of squares with total area 1.

| Authors | Year | Upper bound |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Moon and Moser [\[14\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0140) | 1967 | 2 |
| Kleitman and Krieger [\[7\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0070) | 1970 | 1.733 |
| Kleitman and Krieger [\[8\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0080) | 1975 | 1.633 |
| Novotný [\[18\]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#br0180) | 1996 | 1.53 |
| Hougardy (this paper) | 2010 | 1.4 |

## 2\. Outline of our proof

In this paper we consider the _rectangle_ [packing problem](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/mathematics/packing-problem). The input is a rectangle _R_ with width _W_ and height _H_, and a list of _n_ rectangles r1,r2,…,ri each with a given width wi and height hi. The question is whether the _n_ rectangles can be packed into _R_ so that no two rectangles [intersect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/mathematics/intersects) in their interiors. We do not allow rotations of the rectangles, i.e., all edges corresponding to the widths of the rectangles have to be parallel.

Our main idea is to reduce the proof of [Theorem 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772111000319#en0010) to a [finite number](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/mathematics/finite-number) of rectangle packing problems. Kleitman and Kriege...

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Two-dimensional packing problem
**Square packing**is a[packing problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packing_problem)where the objective is to determine how many[congruent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_(geometry))[squares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square)can be packed into some larger shape, often a square or circle.
## In a square
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Square_packing&action=edit&section=1)]
**Square packing in a square**is the problem of determining the maximum number of[unit squares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_square)(squares of side length one) that can be packed inside a larger square of side lengtha{\\displaystyle a}![{\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc). Ifa{\\displaystyle a}![{\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc)is an[integer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer), the answer isa2,{\\displaystyle a^{2},}![{\displaystyle a^{2},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de86823f6a2c1491493f6c76e8cc8560469b165c)but the precise –or even[asymptotic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asymptotic)– amount of unfilled space for an arbitrary non-integera{\\displaystyle a}![{\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc)is an open question.[[1]](#cite_note-Brass2005-1)
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/5_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg/250px-5_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:5_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg)
5 unit squares in a square of side length2+1/2≈2.707{\\displaystyle 2+1/{\\sqrt {2}}\\approx 2.707}![{\displaystyle 2+1/{\sqrt {2}}\approx 2.707}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3a83b92873fe91d0165dbe03b2b1bfc49541ed5f)
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/10_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg/250px-10_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:10_kvadratoj_en_kvadrato.svg)
10 unit squares in a square of side length3+1/2≈3.707{\\displaystyle 3+1/{\\sqrt {2}}\\approx 3.707}![{\displaystyle 3+1/{\sqrt {2}}\approx 3.707}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4377f4790101e2a43ab920cca1fa18d9a6a57851)
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Packing_11_unit_squares_in_a_square_with_side_length_3.87708359....svg/250px-Packing_11_unit_squares_in_a_square_with_side_length_3.87708359....svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Packing_11_unit_squares_in_a_square_with_side_length_3.87708359....svg)
11 unit squares in a square of side lengtha≈3.877084{\\displaystyle a\\approx 3.877084}![{\displaystyle a\approx 3.877084}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4bc9f18ee286d162697418f187eb6f7c42405ccc)
The smallest value ofa{\\displaystyle a}![{\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc)that allows the packing ofn{\\displaystyle n}![{\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)unit squares is known whenn{\\displaystyle n}![{\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)is a perfect square (in which case it isn{\\displaystyle {\\sqrt {n}}}![{\displaystyle {\sqrt {n}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2a2994734eae382ce30100fb17b9447fd8e99f81)), as well as forn={\\displaystyle n={}}![{\displaystyle n={}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/57d39e3020fd7969506c8f1c6e330039e9b97556)2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 13, 14, 15, 24, 34, 35, 46, 47, and 48. For most of these numbers (with the exceptions only of 5 and 10), the packing is the natural one with axis-aligned squares, anda{\\displaystyle a}![{\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc)is⌈n⌉{\\displaystyle \\lceil {\\sqrt {n}}\\,\\rceil }![{\displaystyle \lceil {\sqrt {n}}\,\rceil }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9a0784b4b3595baa87e336cb58ddf6e9821cdbd0), where⌈ ⌉{\\displaystyle \\lceil \\,\\ \\rceil }![{\displaystyle \lceil \,\ \rceil }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4a733c1aa88cc7e4b97df7fb3b27877448b17b05)is the[ceiling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceiling_function)(round up) function.[[2]](#cite_note-ks02-2)[[3]](#cite_note-3)The figure shows the optimal packings for 5 and 10 squares, the two smallest numbers of squares for which the optimal packing involves tilted squares.[[4]](#cite_note-survey-4)[[5]](#cite_note-5)
The smallest unresolved case isn=11{\\displaystyle n=11}![{\displaystyle n=11}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1e7f254d84dfad562e1c9ecd6680b456a5cae01b). It is known that 11 unit squares cannot be packed in a square of side length less than2+45≈3.789{\\displaystyle \\textstyle 2+{\\frac {4}{\\sqrt {5}}}\\approx 3.789}![{\displaystyle \textstyle 2+{\frac {4}{\sqrt {5}}}\approx 3.789}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/28888e7ace0116f25c7d616d5dad1cdfdf49a4a0). By contrast, the tightest known packing of 11 squares is inside a square of side length approximately 3.877084 found by[Walter Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Trump).[[4]](#cite_note-survey-4)[[6]](#cite_note-6)
The smallest case where the best known packing involves squares at three different angles isn=17{\\displaystyle n=17}![{\displaystyle n=17}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a6e46a4d943792d42029127bbd1f9295c166bf8b). It was discovered in 1998 by John Bidwell, an undergraduate student at the[University of Hawaiʻi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Hawai%CA%BBi), and has side lengtha≈4.6756{\\displaystyle a\\approx 4.6756}![{\displaystyle a\approx 4.6756}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/337e2040d112ef357ddffaa153235b728c470125).[[4]](#cite_note-survey-4)

# Christmas Tree Template

November 13, 2020

_by_

[Debbie Chapman](https://onelittleproject.com/author/dlvchapman/)

- Pin for Later2179

[Save as Favorite](https://onelittleproject.com/christmas-tree-template/)

_This site runs ads and generates income from affiliate links. Read my_
_[disclosure policy](https://onelittleproject.com/disclosure/)._

Looking for a Christmas tree template for your next holiday craft project or activity? We’ve got you covered! Below you’ll find **8 different Christmas tree shapes** in all different sizes – Both super simple tree templates and more complicated tree outlines for preschoolers, kids, teens and adults. Use them as a stencil or pattern, or even just as a Christmas tree coloring sheet.

There’s **25 different printable pages** and they’re all free for you to download and print! These Christmas tree shapes are great for Christmas crafts, camping crafts, holiday school activities and really any craft or activity where you might need one (or many!) evergreen tree shapes.

See the end of this post for some fun ways to use these templates.

**RELATED:** [Snowflake Template](https://onelittleproject.com/snowflake-template/)

[![Christmas Tree Template](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20650%20864'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Shapes.pdf)

_These printables are for **personal and school use only**. Do not copy, republish, upload or alter these files. If you would like to feature these printables please provide a link back to this webpage._

## What to do with these Christmas tree templates:

- Use the Christmas tree template as a **pattern or stencil** for your next holiday craft.
- **Cut out the Christmas tree outline**, color it, add pom poms, rhinestones and a [star](https://onelittleproject.com/star-template/).
- **Trace the evergreen trees** onto construction paper and cut them out to make your own holiday decorations.
- Use the Christmas tree patterns for **games or learning activities.**

## Christmas Tree Outline \#1:

A classic Christmas tree shape that’s perfect for your holiday crafting needs. With slightly curved points, this tree shape is easy to cut out and fun to decorate.

[![Christmas Tree Outline](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20500%20627'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline.pdf)

Christmas Tree Outline #1 Options:

[**Large** (full page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline.pdf)

[**Medium** (2 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-Medium.pdf)

[**Small** (8 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-Small.pdf)

## Christmas Tree Outline \#2:

With mostly straight lines, this fatter tree shape is a little more modern and easy to cut out. Cut out white trees, glue them to dark blue construction paper, and add rhinestones to the sky to make a snowy landscape.

[![Christmas Tree Outline 2](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20500%20627'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-2.pdf)

Christmas Tree Outline #2 Options:

[**Large** (full page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-2.pdf)

[**Medium** (2 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-2-Medium.pdf)

[**Small** (8 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-2-Small.pdf)

## Christmas Tree Outline \#3:

This tree design is a taller, skinny evergreen shape. It’s beautiful on it’s own, but also a great option when you want to combine different tree shapes in your craft.

[![Christmas Tree Outline 3](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20500%20627'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-3.pdf)

Christmas Tree Outline #3 Options:

[**Large** (full page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-3.pdf)

[**Medium** (2 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-3-Medium.pdf)

[**Small** (8 per page)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Outline-3-Small.pdf)

## Christmas Tree Shape \#4:

This Christmas tree design has all curved edges, but it’s still simple to cut out. Try gluing it to the front of a holiday greeting card and decorating it with glitter glue.

[![Christmas Tree Shape](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20500%20627'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Shape.pdf)

This Christmas tree design is perfect for coloring. With a pretty star on top, this detailed template is ready to decorate!

## Christmas Tree Template \#6:

The next few tree shapes are perfect for kids crafts. The simple templates are really easy for small hands to cut out.

## Christmas Tree Template \#7:

This simple, kid-friendly template is just like the previous one, but with 4 levels of tree points instead of 3 levels.

[![Christmas Tree Template 2](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20500%20627'%3E%3C/svg%3E)](https://onelittleproject.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Christmas-Tree-Template-2.pdf)
